title: 114_hr4731
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Refugee Program Integrity Restoration Act of 2016" and includes provisions for the annual adjustment of the number of admissible refugees. The "Refugee Program Integrity Restoration Act of 2016" amends the Immigration and Nationality Act regarding the number of admissible refugees. The President can recommend revisions to the refugee number for humanitarian concerns or national interest. In cases of emergencies, the President can recommend a specific number of refugees to Congress. The "Refugee Program Integrity Restoration Act of 2016" allows the President to recommend changes to the number of admissible refugees for humanitarian or national interest reasons. In emergencies, the President can suggest a specific refugee number to Congress. Section 207(c) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to require that aliens seeking refuge due to persecution must prove their case based on race, religion, or nationality. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to require aliens seeking refuge to prove their case based on race, religion, nationality, membership in a social group, or political opinion. The Secretary must submit an annual report to Congress on terminations of status under this provision. Priority consideration for certain applicants for refugee status is provided for in Section 4. Section 207(c) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to grant priority consideration to refugee applicants from countries listed as 'Countries of Particular Concern' for persecution based on religion. Amend section 207(c) of the Immigration and Nationality Act to prioritize refugee applicants from 'Countries of Particular Concern' for religious persecution by replacing "Attorney General" with "Secretary of Homeland Security". SEC. 5 amends the Immigration and Nationality Act regarding the admission of refugees. SEC. 6 allows for recurrent security monitoring of admitted refugees. SEC. 7 addresses the adjustment of status for refugees. SEC. 7 amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to adjust the status of refugees by changing the time requirement to 3 years. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to change grounds for inadmissibility and deportability, requiring in-person interviews and clear evidence for adjustment of status. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to require in-person interviews and clear evidence for adjustment of status for refugees. Additionally, refugees denied admission must undergo reexamination every 5 years to determine eligibility for immigrant status. SEC. 9. LIMITATION ON RESETTLEMENT.

Amendment to the Immigration and Nationality Act adds a provision limiting refugee resettlement in states or localities where officials have formally disapproved of it.

SEC. 10. BENEFIT FRAUD ASSESSMENT. SEC. 10. BENEFIT FRAUD ASSESSMENT. The Fraud Detection and National Security Directorate of U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services will conduct a study on refugee processing to identify common fraud methods and recommend prevention measures. A report will be submitted to the House and Senate Judiciary Committees. The Secretary of Homeland Security will establish a program to detect fraudulent documents in refugee admission applications, including placing officials at initial screening and creating a searchable database of scanned documents for fraud detection. SEC. 12. RECORDING OF INTERVIEWS TO PROTECT REFUGEES AND PREVENT FRAUD. The Secretary of Homeland Security must use digital recording technology to record interviews of aliens applying for refugee admission. Additionally, a random selection of interviews with interpreters must be audited to ensure accurate interpretation before approving or denying refugee applications. If the interpreter incorrectly interprets any part of the interview, they will be banned from future immigration interpretation. The application will be put on hold until the applicant is re-interviewed. SEC. 13 amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to limit qualification as a refugee based on displacement or fleeing from violence in the person's country of nationality. The violence must be specifically directed at the person based on race, religion, nationality, social group, or political opinion. SEC. 14 addresses security requirements for refugees. SEC. 14 outlines security requirements for refugees entering the United States, including background checks by the Secretary of Homeland Security to ensure they do not pose a national security threat. The Comptroller General of the United States will review and report to Congress on the security of the U.S. Refugee Admissions Program, including how security screening and background checks are conducted, how eligibility for refugee resettlement is determined, and the number of refugees convicted in terrorism-related investigations since fiscal year. The U.S. Government has been investigating federally funded benefit programs for aliens admitted under the Immigration and Nationality Act since 2006.
